Round Problem Description: Critical Ethereum clients, compilers, libraries, and shared infrastructure remain structurally underfunded despite securing and enabling applications worth billions. Maintainers face unstable resource availability and lack predictable support, forcing tradeoffs between commercial work and sustaining essential public goods.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Ensuring multiple Ethereum client implementations (Prysm, Lighthouse, Geth, Nethermind, etc.) remain robust and in sync. This requires ongoing support for client teams and testing to prevent consensus splits.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Round Problem Description: Critical Ethereum clients, compilers, libraries, and shared infrastructure remain structurally underfunded despite securing and enabling applications worth billions. Maintainers face unstable resource availability and lack predictable support, forcing tradeoffs between commercial work and sustaining essential public goods.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Relying on a single majority client is dangerous where a critical bug could halt the network. Increasing usage of minority clients and funding client teams is necessary to strengthen the protocol’s resilience.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Unchecked MEV and centralization can undermine Ethereum’s credibility and security. While MEV research (e.g. PBS, CRList) is active, solutions are nascent and ecosystem urgency is growing as MEV revenue and staking centralization climb.

Round Problem Description: Developers face complex, fragmented workflows across languages, frameworks, debugging tools, and testing environments. Tooling is inconsistent, lacks standardization, and often depends on volunteer-maintained components that evolve slowly or lack coordination.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Many widely-used Ethereum libraries, frameworks, and languages (solidity compilers, testing frameworks, etc.) are maintained by small teams on shoestring budgets. Gaps or bugs in these core tools can lead to security issues or slow development for hundreds of projects.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Round Problem Description: Developers face complex, fragmented workflows across languages, frameworks, debugging tools, and testing environments. Tooling is inconsistent, lacks standardization, and often depends on volunteer-maintained components that evolve slowly or lack coordination.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: High-quality IDEs, debuggers, formal verification tools, and security analysis software are needed to help developers write safe and efficient contracts. Without better tooling, developers may inadvertently deploy vulnerabilities or turn to more centralized tech to fill gaps
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Round Problem Description: Developers lack accessible, effective tools to prevent vulnerabilities, validate assumptions, and detect security issues early. Security-critical tooling is underfunded, leaving gaps in auditing, verification, fuzzing, and safe development practices.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Bugs in DeFi protocols and NFTs have led to frequent hacks. Many projects prioritized growth over security best practices, resulting in reentrancy, oracle manipulation, and logic flaws. There is a need for better auditing, formal verification tools, and secure-by-design frameworks to reduce contract bugs.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: While top projects and the Ethereum Foundation invest in security, many vulnerabilities persist, and underfundedness is evident in areas like open-source auditing tools and formal verification (which receive less attention than flashy dApps).

Round Problem Description: Ethereum’s scaling roadmap requires constant advancement in clients, languages, rollup tooling, data availability systems, statelessness, account abstraction, and protocol readiness. Many of these areas lack the necessary research-to-implementation tooling bridge.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Many widely-used Ethereum libraries, frameworks, and languages (solidity compilers, testing frameworks, etc.) are maintained by small teams on shoestring budgets. Gaps or bugs in these core tools can lead to security issues or slow development for hundreds of projects.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Round Problem Description: Developers lack accessible, reliable, open-source data analytics, indexing, observability tooling, and onchain insights. Existing data systems are fragmented or proprietary, limiting visibility into application behavior, network performance, and developer productivity.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Public goods like block explorers, analytics dashboards, and indexing protocols (The Graph, etc.) enable the community to query and understand blockchain data. Supporting open indexing infrastructure and common data standards ensures transparency and eases development (projects don’t each need to build their own indexers).
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Round Problem Description: Critical maintainers lack stable resources and must balance public goods work with commercial activity. Many teams lack fundraising support or business development capabilities. This results in unstable roadmaps, burnout, and a persistent risk of maintainers abandoning essential public goods.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: How to continuously deploy funds to essential projects (clients, libraries, research) without relying on one-off grants or altruism. Challenges include designing funding streams (treasury inflows, protocol revenue allocation) and deciding when and how funds should flow for maximum impact.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Sustaining Ethereum’s long-term progress requires robust public goods funding (PGF) and governance mechanisms. The past few years have seen multiple experiments (Gitcoin QF rounds, DAO grants, Protocol Guild, Optimism RetroPGF, etc.), yet several core problems remain unsolved in funding Ethereum’s public goods.

Round Problem Description: Ethereum’s growth across L1, L2s, rollups, and app-specific chains has created silos of data, liquidity, and activity. Core ecosystem metrics and behaviors remain scattered, inconsistent, or locked behind proprietary interfaces. This fragmentation reduces the ability of builders, funders, and policymakers to assess ecosystem health reliably.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Public goods like block explorers, analytics dashboards, and indexing protocols (The Graph, etc.) enable the community to query and understand blockchain data. Supporting open indexing infrastructure and common data standards ensures transparency and eases development (projects don’t each need to build their own indexers).
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Round Problem Description: Ethereum’s growth across L1, L2s, rollups, and app-specific chains has created silos of data, liquidity, and activity. Core ecosystem metrics and behaviors remain scattered, inconsistent, or locked behind proprietary interfaces. This fragmentation reduces the ability of builders, funders, and policymakers to assess ecosystem health reliably.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: The Ethereum ecosystem now spans L1, many L2s, and sidechains. Standards for messaging and bridging (like ERC standards, CCIP, or trust-minimized bridges) are needed so that these networks can interoperate safely. Without common standards, we risk fragmentation and security holes between chains.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Round Problem Description: Ethereum’s rollups and applications lack consistent, widely adopted interoperability standards for messaging, execution, and intent schemas. This forces each project to create custom integrations and adapters, increasing operational complexity and reducing cross-chain reliability.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Scaling solutions must seamlessly integrate (L1↔L2 and L2↔L2). Efficient bridging and interoperability standards are needed so users can move assets across shards and rollups without trust tradeoffs.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Ethereum’s foremost challenge is scaling network throughput to meet global demand. The Surge roadmap focuses on scaling via sharding and rollups to reach ~100,000 transactions per second.

Round Problem Description: APIs, SDKs, solver frameworks, and execution environments needed for seamless cross-chain interaction are still early-stage or missing. Builders must work around inconsistent interfaces across L1s, L2s, and application chains, raising integration costs and slowing innovation.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Many widely-used Ethereum libraries, frameworks, and languages (solidity compilers, testing frameworks, etc.) are maintained by small teams on shoestring budgets. Gaps or bugs in these core tools can lead to security issues or slow development for hundreds of projects.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Round Problem Description: The Open Intents Framework (OIF) remains early in adoption, with limited analytics, tooling, solver coverage, and production pilots. Without measurement systems and usable infrastructure, intent-based execution cannot become a network-wide standard.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: The Ethereum ecosystem now spans L1, many L2s, and sidechains. Standards for messaging and bridging (like ERC standards, CCIP, or trust-minimized bridges) are needed so that these networks can interoperate safely. Without common standards, we risk fragmentation and security holes between chains.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Round Problem Description: Critical data about usage, risk, governance, and cross-chain flows remains locked behind proprietary platforms or inconsistent methodologies. Without open, verifiable metrics, builders and funders cannot make evidence-based decisions, and the ecosystem loses transparency.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Public goods like block explorers, analytics dashboards, and indexing protocols (The Graph, etc.) enable the community to query and understand blockchain data. Supporting open indexing infrastructure and common data standards ensures transparency and eases development (projects don’t each need to build their own indexers).
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Beyond the protocol and developer tools, the ecosystem relies on a broad infrastructure layer that includes client software, networking, cross-chain coordination, and data access. This category covers the “plumbing” that many take for granted.

Problem: Coordination Barriers for Builders and Funders
Round Problem Description: Builders, researchers, DAOs, and funders lack shared interfaces and evaluation frameworks for understanding interoperability needs, duplications, and system-level priorities. This leads to misaligned funding, reinvented tooling, and slow consensus on where ecosystem investment is most impactful.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Many dev tools are open-source public goods that see duplicated effort and lack sustainable funding. Better coordination (e.g. shared standards, grants, and recognition for maintainer work) can reduce fragmentation.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Round Problem Description: Most activity on Ethereum occurs in full public view, with transfers, trades and interactions easily traceable by anyone. Wallets ship without privacy defaults, and users have no seamless, built-in protection. Privacy infrastructure exists but is fragmented, hard to adopt, and not widely integrated across the ecosystem.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Currently, any on-chain activity is visible to all, which is unsuitable for sensitive applications. Zero-knowledge proofs and zkSNARK-based constructions can enable private transactions or shielded token transfers, but integrating these at scale (e.g. layer-2 privacy chains or L1 shielded pools) is an open problem.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Given that the Ethereum Foundation and community have only a few dedicated teams (e.g. PSE) and grants focusing on privacy, this area is relatively under-resourced. It deserves prioritization to ensure Ethereum doesn’t lose users to more privacy-centric chains, and to uphold values like civil liberties in the Web3 era.

Round Problem Description: The ecosystem lacks robust, widely adopted ZK primitives, proving systems, and developer tooling. Current frameworks require specialized expertise, remain hard to integrate, and limit experimentation. Many core mechanisms for private computation, messaging, voting, and identity remain early stage.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Users lack native ways to prove identity or credentials without revealing private data. Solutions like decentralized identity (DID) standards, attestations, or Soulbound Tokens are being explored, but ensuring they preserve privacy (selective disclosure, zk-credentials) is key for broad adoption in areas like credit, reputation, or government services.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Given that the Ethereum Foundation and community have only a few dedicated teams (e.g. PSE) and grants focusing on privacy, this area is relatively under-resourced. It deserves prioritization to ensure Ethereum doesn’t lose users to more privacy-centric chains, and to uphold values like civil liberties in the Web3 era.

Round Problem Description: The ecosystem lacks robust, widely adopted ZK primitives, proving systems, and developer tooling. Current frameworks require specialized expertise, remain hard to integrate, and limit experimentation. Many core mechanisms for private computation, messaging, voting, and identity remain early stage.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Wider use of ZK proofs faces usability and performance hurdles (circuit complexity, prover time). Research into more efficient proving systems, hardware acceleration (ZK ASICs), and developer-friendly ZK libraries is crucial. The Verge and other roadmap items rely on ZK tech to make light clients viable, underscoring its importance beyond just privacy.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Given that the Ethereum Foundation and community have only a few dedicated teams (e.g. PSE) and grants focusing on privacy, this area is relatively under-resourced. It deserves prioritization to ensure Ethereum doesn’t lose users to more privacy-centric chains, and to uphold values like civil liberties in the Web3 era.

Round Problem Description: Privacy-preserving dApps exist but struggle with adoption due to complexity, unclear UX, limited integrations, and uncertain trust signals. Even when privacy features are implemented, usage often remains low and fragmented.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Many decentralized applications have clunky UI/UX compared to Web2. Better design principles, performant front-ends, and user-centric features (human-readable names, gas estimations, fee smoothing) will make Ethereum apps more accessible
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Ethereum’s scalability impact and security both ultimately benefit from broader adoption: more users bring more value and security to the network, and real-world applications drive demand for scalability and privacy features.

Round Problem Description: Ethereum lacks reliable, user-controlled identity systems that preserve privacy. Many digital identity tools expose linkages between accounts, activities, and off-chain profiles. Private identity solutions remain early, fragmented, or hard to integrate.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Users lack native ways to prove identity or credentials without revealing private data. Solutions like decentralized identity (DID) standards, attestations, or Soulbound Tokens are being explored, but ensuring they preserve privacy (selective disclosure, zk-credentials) is key for broad adoption in areas like credit, reputation, or government services.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Given that the Ethereum Foundation and community have only a few dedicated teams (e.g. PSE) and grants focusing on privacy, this area is relatively under-resourced. It deserves prioritization to ensure Ethereum doesn’t lose users to more privacy-centric chains, and to uphold values like civil liberties in the Web3 era.

Round Problem Description: Most governance on Ethereum is conducted in public, revealing voter preferences, social relationships, and strategic positions. Private voting systems exist but remain early stage, difficult to deploy, and not widely integrated.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Balancing privacy with compliance is an ecosystem-level challenge. How can Ethereum support use cases like private DAOs or confidential business logic, while still allowing auditability where required? Mechanisms such as viewing keys or zero-knowledge regulatory proofs need development.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Given that the Ethereum Foundation and community have only a few dedicated teams (e.g. PSE) and grants focusing on privacy, this area is relatively under-resourced. It deserves prioritization to ensure Ethereum doesn’t lose users to more privacy-centric chains, and to uphold values like civil liberties in the Web3 era.

Problem: Lack of Privacy Education and Field Building
Round Problem Description: Developers and users often lack understanding of privacy risks, available tools, and correct implementation patterns. Educational resources are scattered, inconsistent, or outdated. This limits adoption and slows the growth of the privacy ecosystem.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Steep learning curves and evolving best practices can discourage new Ethereum developers. Clear, up-to-date documentation, interactive tutorials, and educational resources are essential to grow the pool of competent builders.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: This area is crucial for scalability (better dev tools lead to more efficient and secure dApps, which indirectly improves network performance) and for risk reduction (preventing hacks through improved tooling).

Problem: Lack of Privacy Education and Field Building
Round Problem Description: Developers and users often lack understanding of privacy risks, available tools, and correct implementation patterns. Educational resources are scattered, inconsistent, or outdated. This limits adoption and slows the growth of the privacy ecosystem.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: There is still a knowledge gap for new users and developers unfamiliar with Web3. Public education, clear documentation, and outreach programs help demystify Ethereum and attract the next wave of users/developers
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Ethereum’s scalability impact and security both ultimately benefit from broader adoption: more users bring more value and security to the network, and real-world applications drive demand for scalability and privacy features.

Round Problem Description: Public goods funding decisions are often difficult to explain, audit, or justify due to opaque criteria, informal judgment, and limited use of structured evidence.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Determining who decides funding priorities and how to aggregate preferences is an open question. Quadratic funding, token-weight votes, and committee review each have trade-offs in fairness and efficiency. The community is still exploring how to best allocate resources in a way that reflects ecosystem needs without succumbing to plutocracy or collusion.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Sustaining Ethereum’s long-term progress requires robust public goods funding (PGF) and governance mechanisms. The past few years have seen multiple experiments (Gitcoin QF rounds, DAO grants, Protocol Guild, Optimism RetroPGF, etc.), yet several core problems remain unsolved in funding Ethereum’s public goods.

Round Problem Description: Funding systems lack reliable ways to assess, compare, or learn from the real-world impact of funded public goods initiatives.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Without clear impact feedback loops, it’s hard to know which grants actually benefited Ethereum. Developing impact evaluation standards (e.g. on-chain attestations, retroactive rewards for proven success) is vital. This ties into governance: holding fund recipients accountable and rewarding truly valuable work.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 1) Descri: Sustaining Ethereum’s long-term progress requires robust public goods funding (PGF) and governance mechanisms. The past few years have seen multiple experiments (Gitcoin QF rounds, DAO grants, Protocol Guild, Optimism RetroPGF, etc.), yet several core problems remain unsolved in funding Ethereum’s public goods.

Round Problem Description: Relevant data about projects, communities, and funding outcomes is scattered across platforms, formats, and stakeholders, limiting holistic understanding.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Multiple entities (EF, DAOs, Gitcoin, L2s, etc.) fund ecosystem projects, but coordination is limited. Better communication and co-funding initiatives can prevent duplication and ensure critical gaps don’t fall through the cracks.

Round Problem Description: As funding ecosystems grow, manual or ad hoc decision processes struggle to scale across many proposals, domains, or communities.
Mapped Ethereum Problem (Level 2) Descri: Broadly, aligning the community on protocol changes and funding priorities is a sociotechnical challenge. Mechanisms like Ethereum’s rough consensus and off-chain governance work, but as more capital and users are at stake, refining governance (possibly through delegated domain experts, on-chain signaling, etc.) will be important to manage growth without centralization.
